title: Old handwriting
content:
Im searching a font like the number on this image with a long bottom leg

Thanks

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905042158im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/90ac_1_4897.jpg)

 [‹ "Harper's Weekly" somewhat clunky serif titling caps](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905042158/http:/www.typophile.com/node/41073 "Go to previous forum topic") [Numbering Machine font ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905042158/http:/www.typophile.com/node/41690 "Go to next forum topic")
author: RickyD

comments.content: [MVB Sirenne](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905042158/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/mvb_fonts/mvb_sirenne_display/) is based on a similar lettering style.
Zildjian had their first American plant in the town where I live, Quincy, MA!

not really the same, but a nice flavor might be texas hero...  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/3ip/texas-hero/](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905042158/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/3ip/texas-hero/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/3ip/texas-hero/")

HLPS Atlas Italic is close to your sample. It, and a bunch of other period fonts can be found here:

[http://www.cthulhulives.org/toybox/PROPDOCS/PropFonts.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20080905042158/http:/www.cthulhulives.org/toybox/PROPDOCS/PropFonts.html "http://www.cthulhulives.org/toybox/PROPDOCS/PropFonts.html")

Note that these fonts have all been scanned from period advertisements, newspapers, documents, etc. Their target audience is a mix of prop makers and H.P Lovecraft reenactors(!) These are pretty rough, but their warts-and-all may be part of their attraction.
